title: Con D. Oriano - The Hidden D. Clan Member
theory: Many fans jokingly theorize that Inspector Shepherd, whom Usopp names 'Condoriano', is actually a member of the Will of D. clan with the true name 'Con D. Oriano'. This plays on the mysterious and powerful D. clan that includes characters like Monkey D. Luffy and Gol D. Roger. Fans create elaborate jokes about Condoriano being the strongest character in One Piece or a secret 10th member of the Straw Hat crew.
author: One Piece Fan Community
supportingEvidence: Usopp convincingly lies that Shepherd is their crewmate named 'Condoriano'
Even Zoro plays along with the ruse, adding legitimacy to the joke
The name 'Con D. Oriano' follows the D. clan naming pattern
counterEvidence: Shepherd is explicitly a Marine Inspector from headquarters
The entire G-8 Arc is non-canon filler
It's clearly a comedic moment with no serious lore implications

title: G-8 Arc Should Be Canon
theory: Many fans theorize or wish that the G-8 Arc should have been part of the official One Piece manga and canon storyline. The theory suggests that the arc's quality, character development, Jonathan's brilliance as an antagonist, and natural flow from Skypiea make it worthy of canon status. Some fans believe Oda may have consulted on the arc's creation given its seamless integration with canon elements.
author: One Piece Fan Community
supportingEvidence: The arc seamlessly follows the Skypiea landing
Jonathan is one of the best-written antagonists in the anime
The arc was reportedly planned as a theatrical film
Character moments feel authentic to Oda's writing
Uses Sky Island elements (gold, waver, dials) effectively
counterEvidence: The arc does not appear in the manga at all
Oda has never mentioned involvement in the G-8 Arc
The arc takes place in a temporal gap between manga chapters
G-8 base never appears again in canon storyline

title: Jonathan's Strategic Genius Foreshadows Future Marine Officers
theory: Some fans theorize that Vice Admiral Jonathan's tactical brilliance and honorable character in the G-8 Arc served as a template or inspiration for later canon Marine officers, particularly those who question absolute justice. His ability to outthink the Straw Hats while remaining morally upright may have influenced the portrayal of characters like Smoker, Fujitora, and other Marines who value justice over blind obedience.
author: One Piece Analysis Community
supportingEvidence: Jonathan predates several 'good' Marine officers in the canon timeline
His characterization shares similarities with later sympathetic Marines
The G-8 Arc aired in 2004, before many canon Marine character developments
Jonathan's fishing and chess metaphors show sophisticated tactical thinking
counterEvidence: Oda may not have been involved in Jonathan's creation
Smoker and other sympathetic Marines already existed before G-8
Character archetypes of 'good soldiers' are common in fiction
No official confirmation of any connection

title: The Condoriano Gag Proves Usopp's Con Artist Evolution
theory: Fans theorize that the Condoriano scene (episode 200) and Usopp's leadership in episode 204 demonstrate Usopp's growth from a simple liar to a sophisticated con artist and tactician. The theory suggests these moments foreshadow Usopp's later development as 'God Usopp' in Dressrosa, showing his ability to manipulate situations and lead when necessary.
author: One Piece Character Analysis Community
supportingEvidence: Usopp successfully convinces Marines that Shepherd is 'Condoriano'
In episode 204, Usopp demonstrates strategic planning and leadership
The crew trusts and follows Usopp's tactical decisions
These moments show Usopp's growth beyond just lying for comic effect
Later canon events show Usopp's strategic value (Dressrosa, Wano)
counterEvidence: G-8 is non-canon and may not reflect Oda's intended character development
Usopp's character growth in canon follows a different trajectory
The filler arc writers may have different interpretation of Usopp
Retroactive pattern-seeking may create false connections
